name: nytimes
text:
“We all must shine a spotlight on the immorality of racial discrimination. But violence, whether spontaneous or consciously incited, is not a solution,” former President Jimmy Carter said in response to protests following George Floyd’s killing.
https://t.co/fZDELgV6gO https://t.co/0eGiFl07wa

name: nytimes
text:
George Floyd had the coronavirus in early April, a full autopsy report from the Hennepin County medical examiner revealed, and continued to test positive at the time of his death
https://t.co/qPB0QllXMq

name: nytimes
text: Some of those who criticized Drew Brees’s remarks were prominent professional sports figures, including members of his own team https://t.co/Tb9P1J77l1

name: nytimes
text: Hours before New York's citywide curfew went into effect Wednesday at 8 p.m., peaceful protesters lined streets in Brooklyn chanting, “Whose streets? Our streets!” Motorists honked in support. Live updates: https://t.co/XjPUsjYgcr https://t.co/kEdD7nxOf3

name: nytimes
text: A large protest formed Wednesday afternoon in West Hollywood, California, with the National Guard staged not far away. Guard members armed with automatic rifles walked past parents pushing strollers at a farmer's market. Live updates: https://t.co/bgDfwNKjTq https://t.co/q6amW62Zyy

name: nytimes
text: RT @zwoolfe: What are the 5 minutes that would make someone fall in love with the cello? (As if it takes that long!) We asked Yo-Yo Ma, John Williams, Andrew Lloyd Webber and others to pick the music that moves them.  https://t.co/Oe7nsLSezw

name: nytimes
text: “Donald Trump is the first president in my lifetime who does not try to unite the American people — does not even pretend to try,” former Defense Secretary Jim Mattis wrote in a statement issued late Wednesday https://t.co/8f0zollDBd

name: nytimes
text: A longtime friend of George Floyd who was in the passenger seat of Floyd’s car when he was arrested said on Wednesday night that Floyd attempted to defuse the tensions with the police and did not resist https://t.co/ehxcjH79iQ

name: nytimes
text: Many readers and New York Times staff members denounced The Times's publication of an opinion essay by Senator Tom Cotton, Republican of Arkansas, that called for a military response to protests. The Times union said that the Op-Ed "promotes hate." https://t.co/yG7CXoUz3c

name: nytimes
text: RT @nytopinion: "As Atlanta’s mayor, I would like to offer one salient solution to the atrocities we are faced with today," says @KeishaBottoms. "Let us commit to registering black people, especially black men, to vote."  https://t.co/OduyFvSe5c

name: nytimes
text:
RT @ByMikeBaker: NEW:

An autopsy has found that Manuel Ellis, a black man who died in police custody in Tacoma, was killed as a result of oxygen deprivation and the physical restraint used in his arrest. 

"I can't breathe," he said before he died.

https://t.co/SOJk8oaMsl

name: nytimes
text: A witness who was in George Floyd’s car during his fatal encounter with a police officer said that Floyd tried to defuse the tensions with the police and in no way resisted arrest. “I could hear him pleading, ‘Please, officer, what’s all this for?’” https://t.co/8Tpopimidn

name: nytimes
text: All officers involved in the killing of George Floyd have now been charged. Many protesters said the new charges would not quell the demonstrations, which were seeking broader systemic changes to the nation’s justice system. https://t.co/cgP0l7GAWW

name: nytimes
text:
RT @EricaLG: “I’m a key witness to the cops murdering George Floyd..." Mr. Hall said in the interview with The Times. "Whatever I’ve been through, it’s all over with now. It’s not about me.”

Passenger in George Floyd's car, now a key witness in the case, emerges: https://t.co/v6ed2ft2TF

name: nytimes
text:
Los Angeles officials estimated that there have been at least 3,000 arrests during the protests over the killing of George Floyd that began more than a week ago.

Live updates of ongoing protests across the U.S.: https://t.co/2VBiLZKMkS https://t.co/kuoaJLlOcQ

name: nytimes
text: A police officer in California shot and killed a kneeling man after mistaking a hammer in the man’s pocket for a gun, the authorities said. The man, Sean Monterrosa, who was Hispanic, was attempting to flee a Walgreens that was being looted. https://t.co/ODZZyk8YZK https://t.co/0290ApsXOk

name: nytimes
text: RT @helenecooper: Chaos at the Pentagon. https://t.co/7Orv6OqWEu via @NYTimes

name: nytimes
text:
Demonstrators marched on Wednesday in New York, Washington and Los Angeles, among other cities, defying curfews but also avoiding confrontation with the police.

Live updates: https://t.co/4wzbpGdhLR https://t.co/kw3PLDUSci

text: RT @suilee: On this fateful day in China, 31 years ago. https://t.co/8HiTpNcHMH

name: nytimes
text: At least 2 police officers were wounded in an altercation in Brooklyn late Wednesday night, the police said. It was unclear whether the confrontation was connected to protests or looting. https://t.co/AZlUFMcXf5

name: nytimes
text: Europe morning briefing: Here's what you need to know to start your day https://t.co/yZ99QnEDb6

name: nytimes
text: By imposing its will on Hong Kong in a way that could provoke international retaliation and damage the city's standing, China is betting its position is strong while the rest of the world is divided. https://t.co/XqTejRJc8u

name: nytimes
text: RT @nytmay: An annual candlelight vigil commemorating the June 4th crackdown has been banned  in Hong Kong over social distancing regulations. Many say they will observe the anniversary and to keep what one lawmaker calls the "lighthouse of memory" flickering.  https://t.co/4lytNkjPy5

name: nytimes
text: An Afghan police officer who killed 2 American military advisers in 2012 was freed from prison last week after serving less than 4 years of a 20-year sentence https://t.co/4c6IrRy1HC

name: nytimes
text: On every June 4 since 1990, huge crowds of Hong Kongers joined in a vigil to remember the loss of lives in Tiananmen Square in 1989. This year, for the first time, Hong Kong will not have the chance to officially remember an event it cannot forget. https://t.co/MhOvNCIAp3

name: nytimes
text: A knife-wielding security guard went on a rampage at an elementary school in southeastern China on Thursday, leaving at least 39 people injured https://t.co/l7SpKJgieQ

name: nytimes
text: The organizers of an annual vigil in Hong Kong for the violent crackdown on the Tiananmen protests in China said they plan to gather Thursday evening despite a first-ever police ban of the event https://t.co/WP5wAPv3Gh

name: nytimes
text: North Korea lashed out at both Seoul and Washington on Thursday, threatening to scrap key parts of agreements with South Korea and comparing the United States to a setting sun being eclipsed by China https://t.co/h99cidcme7

name: nytimes
text: The world has been transfixed by the unrest in the U.S. A 92-year-old Italian says he sees the ghost of Mussolini in TV coverage. In Iraq, people are sharing photos that compare President Trump holding up a Bible with Saddam Hussein clutching a Quran. https://t.co/UjbFiLIRtj

name: nytimes
text: As Italy reopens its museums after a 3-month lockdown, locals are keen to reclaim the country’s monuments. But cultural institutions worry about the loss of much-needed revenue from ticket sales to tourists. https://t.co/fN3Tjb46Vr

name: nytimes
text: Breaking News: Hong Kong made it a crime to mock China’s national anthem, as activists planned to commemorate the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown despite a ban https://t.co/gS9lnxICpi

name: nytimes
text: Can Venice, a city whose history and culture drew tens of millions of visitors a year, reinvent itself? The coronavirus may give it a chance to try. https://t.co/wVi01LDZq1

name: nytimes
text: Steve Linick, an inspector general who was fired from the State Department, told Congress that a friend of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo tried to “bully” him as he examined potential misconduct by the administration https://t.co/3VLrMtJHKr

name: nytimes
text: RT @nytimesworld: The photographs from the 1989 protests in Tiananmen Square — initially buoyant, then dramatic, then tragic — are some of the most indelible news images of the last 100 years https://t.co/fYAGKxf5aM

name: nytimes
text: At a time when funeral gatherings are rare because of the coronavirus, a memorial service will honor George Floyd, whose death in police custody has provoked global outrage. The Rev. Al Sharpton will give the eulogy. https://t.co/QoCsUGg58J

name: nytimes
text:
After a 9th day of protests across the U.S., thousands of people planed to gather in Minneapolis for the first of 6 days of memorials for George Floyd

Latest updates: https://t.co/aqv89sfGVX https://t.co/MIvN6ou6x2

name: nytimes
text: RT @jialynnyang: On the 31st anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre, I am re-reading @ChuBailiang's extraordinary piece about one woman's quest to make her country never forget—that during a peaceful protest, its gov't once opened fire on its own citizens. https://t.co/LlMcoSzhiS
